articles.title: React 19 Now in Beta
articles.description: While designed to get library developers prepared for the eventual React 19 release, this is nonetheless a huge step, with full support for Custom Elements (Custom Element support has long been a thorn in React's side), all the latest React Server Components goodies, Actions, use, and more besides.
articles.author: The React Team

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Let Me Be: "const ... Is Stupid and You're Using It Wrong"
articles.description: An entertaining 12-minute talk on misunderstandings around the use of const vs let. This was bound to provoke some strong reactions (see the Twitter thread) but let him make his point!
articles.author: Ryan Florence

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.5 Beta
articles.description: It‚Äôs not even the final release (expect that in a month or two) but 5.5 has many people excited as it has many major enhancements, including inferred type predicates, the ability to import types in JSDoc via comments, regex syntax checking, isolated declarations, and more. If you want more practical examples, Matt Pocock üê¶ wrote a good Twitter thread.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: 'I Reviewed 1,000s of Opinions on HTMX'
articles.description: htmx is an increasingly popular way to use modern, dynamic browser features through creative use of HTML attributes, rather than hand writing JS for everything. Dylan looks at the pros and cons through the lens of community sentiment.
articles.author: Dylan Huang

articles.title: Native Support for CJS/ESM Interoperability Begins in Node 22
articles.description: An overview of a new era for Node developers when working with both CommonJS and ECMAScript modules.
articles.author: Zachary Lee

articles.title: Finally Understanding How Array.sort(comparator) Works
articles.description: ‚ÄúAfter 13 years of JavaScript, I finally have a way to remember how the comparator function in Array.sort() works..‚Äù
articles.author: James Kerr

articles.title: Detecting JavaScript Support in CSS
articles.description: A way to provide alternative CSS rules depending on whether or not JavaScript is available in the user‚Äôs browser.
articles.author: Ryan Mulligan

articles.title: extension.js: Zero-Config, Cross Browser Extension Dev Starter
articles.description: The goal is to make it as simple as a npx extension create my-extension to get started with building your own browser extensions. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Cezar Augusto

articles.title: Layer Cake: A Graphics Framework for Svelte
articles.description: This library gives you a baseline for creating responsive web graphics via common elements (e.g. a coordinate system and scales). See numerous example components here.
articles.author: Layer Cake

articles.title: Tagify 4.26: An Elegant Input Component for Tags
articles.description: The polished demos show a lot of effort has been put in here. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Yair Even-Or

articles.title: Journey.js: No-Dependency Library to Create Interactive Guided Tours
articles.description: The live examples are basic, but the focus on accessibility and built-in support for 51 languages are pluses.
articles.author: William Troup

articles.title: üì∫¬†YouTube.js: Unofficial YouTube API Client Library
articles.description: ‚ÄòInnerTube‚Äô is an API used by YouTube‚Äôs clients, and you can use it too, although they might not like it. It runs on Node.js, Deno, and modern browsers.
articles.author: LuanRT

articles.title: Virtual x86: x86 Virtualization with JS and WASM
articles.description: Run Linux, numerous older versions of Windows, BSD, MS-DOS, and other systems right in the browser (and quickly, too). Not a new project, but I‚Äôm always impressed how it‚Äôs constantly getting updates. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Fabian Hemmer

articles.description: The New Stack has a feature on Ryan Dahl and his opinions on packaging, JSR, and even TypeScript.
MoonBit is a WebAssembly driven cloud platform and it now has a JavaScript backend too that claims to be very fast.
If you noticed the JSDelivr CDN went down earlier, here's why.
Zachary Lee has a quick guide to React 19 Beta taking more of a code-led approach than the release notes.
‚≠êÔ∏è Svelte 5 Release Candidate ‚Äì "no anticipated breaking changes between now and the stable release." In a quick talk, ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Rich Harris explains what's new.
React 18.3 ‚Äì The beta of 19 may be more exciting, but 18.3 will help your app's transition by not breaking anything that works on 18.2 while providing more deprecation warnings.
Bun 1.1.6 ‚Äì Now supports UDP sockets, Array#sort gets a lot faster, and 1.1.5 introduced cross-compilation for standalone executables.
Astro 4.7 ‚Äì There's also a roundup of what's new with the project overall.
Node.js 22.1 (Current) and Deno 1.43

articles.title: An Alternative Proposal for CSS Masonry
articles.description: Last week we shared WebKit‚Äôs thoughts on how to approach creating masonry type layouts in CSS. Now the Chrome team has weighed in, stating that ‚Äúimplementing it as part of the CSS Grid specification [..] would be a mistake‚Äù, and they think it should be its own separate layout method defined using display: masonry or something similar.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew (Chrome)

articles.title: The Popover API is Here
articles.description: The Popover API now has broad support, and as such Chris gives us a brief overview of how it differs from <dialog> and how we may want to approach using it.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: Printing Music with CSS Grid
articles.description: The author notes (pun very much intended) that music notation on the web should be as accessible and fluid as text is - but how do we go about fixing it so musicians don‚Äôt have to fumble pinch-zooming a PDF during a gig? Lots of good examples here and a reminder of just how far you can take CSS!
articles.author: Stephen Band

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Optimizing INP: A Deep Dive
articles.description: A good step-by-step instructional video on digging into responsiveness issues in Chrome‚Äôs Performance Panel (29 minutes).
articles.author: Brendan Kenny (Chrome for Developers)

articles.title: Handling the Indentation of a Treeview Component
articles.description: How should you approach building a UI that contains nested components, with an increasing indentation for each one? Ahmad looks at solving it with CSS.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: Reaction-Diffusion Compute Shader in WebGPU
articles.description: A look at how to use WebGPU compute shaders to create some rather wild looking patterns. Support is limited right now, but it‚Äôs a neat effect.
articles.author: Robert Leitl

articles.title: Passkeys: A Shattered Dream?
articles.description: William, who has his own web auth project, shares some concerns and growing disillusion with passkeys.
articles.author: William Brown

articles.title: DesignSystemHunt: A Curated Collection of Design Systems from Popular Brands
articles.description: Currently includes links and info on 140+ different design systems from various startups, brands, tech companies, etc.
articles.author: DesignSystemHunt

articles.title: extension.js: Zero-Config, Cross Browser Extension Dev Starter
articles.description: The goal is to make it as simple as a npx extension create my-extension to get started with building your own browser extension. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Cezar Augusto

articles.title: Popicons: A Set of Free Figma/SVG Icons in Line, Solid & Duotone Styles
articles.description: Designed in Figma and you can download the whole lot or go directly to the searchable gallery and copy the SVG code directly.
articles.author: Popicons

articles.title: Only <Spans>: Each Element on This Page is a SPAN
articles.description: A silly what-not-to-do experiment that demonstrates the fact that every element on a page can be an HTML <span> element but modified for different roles using CSS.
articles.author: OnlySpans

articles.title: Fluid for Tailwind CSS
articles.description: A fluid clamp() plugin for Tailwind that works with every utility. Repo here.
articles.author: Maxwell Barvian

articles.title: JSON Generator: An Intuitive Tool for Crafting Complex JSON Structures
articles.description: Includes 40+ ‚Äútemplate tags‚Äù (or functions) that you can incorporate into the JSON template so you can generate specific types of content for use in testing, mocking, teaching, and so on.
articles.author: JSON Generator

articles.title: 'Doom' Scroll
articles.description: A neat demo of @scroll-timeline ‚Äî a new CSS property that allows animations to be driven by a container‚Äôs scroll position. YMMV on browser support here.
articles.author: Adam Kuhn
